awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Treatment technology for recovery of valuable metals from industrial wastewater
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is two-pronged: removal of metal  contaminants in wastewater to limit regulatory/environmental costs and recovery of economically valuable metals. Water metal contamination is a ubiquitous problem due to the many industrialized processes that drive our economy. Examples include mining drainage, metal plating, semiconductor fabrication, and solar cell production. These examples straddle well-established and emerging industries but each pose significant environmental impact due to metal contamination potential. Furthermore, the loss of the associated metals carries an economic consequence as un-recovered material represents a significant missed opportunity in raw material utilization. The proposed technology in this Phase I project is poised to address these concerns.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are to produce a novel metal binding compound and to scale-up the water-metal removal prototypes based upon this compound. The project will develop a production system for producing a small molecule natural product capable of binding metal compounds with high affinity. This compound will be bound to a solid matrix which enables a heterogeneous means of removing metal content from contaminated water samples. Existing small-scale production and water treatment prototypes will be subjected to cellular and process engineering to scale up for water treatment applications. This scaling step is considered crucial to establishing the viability of the overall technology and approach. Metabolic engineering strategies will be utilized to improve cellular production of the metal binding compound. Process engineering will be applied to scale production of the compound and to assess subsequent packed-bed column operations designed to continuously remove metals from water samples. The team will work closely with a local metal plating company to demonstrate the technology with field wastewater samples. Success will result in a scaled prototype for extended application across industries facing metal contamination/loss.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

During the course of the work funded by this proposal, we developed a reusable system for water purification employing a natural product, yerseniabactin (Ybt). Over the course of this project, we were able to improve the production of Ybt by >40-fold over our initial production strategy. In addition, we developed a system for the continuous removal of heavy metals from water and increased its operational scale by 20-fold. Upon developing this product, we collaborated with our partner in the metal plating industry (Precious Plate; Buffalo, NY) to test its metal recovery capabilities. During these studies, we demonstrated that our Ybt-containing product is 33% more effective than our partners current system that is used for extracting metals from water. 

Broader Impacts

Our technology’s ability to selectively recover metal species at low concentrations in a cost-efficient manner is particularly useful for metal plating and finishing companies due to the high losses of metals such as nickel, copper, zinc, silver, and gold in their wastewater. We have spoken to over 130 customers in the metal plating industry and in the process, validated the potential market opportunity (i.e., limited solutions for trace metal recovery, low adoption of progressive technologies, and annual losses of >$1 billion). For example, our partner and anticipated first customer, Precious Plate, a mid-sized plating company based out of Niagara Falls, NY, experiences losses of $2-3M worth of precious metals each year despite employing activated carbon to mitigate losses from ~80% of their waste water. Furthermore, they are unable to incorporate additional activated carbon into their processes due to associated labor and storage costs. Interestingly, they reported that replacement of activated carbon twice a day was driven by the observation that activated carbon was unable to recover significant levels of metal after 12 hours (i.e., it becomes saturated with metal.) Fortunately, this is a situation our technology can address through a simple removal step.  Consequently, there is a significant need within this industry for a cost-effective alternative to current technologies for metal recovery.

Although we have targeted the metal plating industry as our initial market, our product also serves to purify water in general. Consequently, our product has the potential to be used within municipalities or the bottled water industry to provide clean drinking water. Alternatively, our product can be used at a smaller scale as a household water filter (with Clorox [Brita] as another customer contacted during the I-Corps process). More broadly, this system could be expanded to address municipal water supplies that are plagued by metal contamination. One notable recent example is the crisis in Flint, Michigan, where large quantities of heavy metal leached into the city’s water supply. We envision that our technology can be employed to combat such catastrophes and help restore tarnished water sources.
